item.title: A Unit Testing Dilemma
item.description: After returning to blogging after a really long hiatus with some really heavy and emotional stuff, I think I’m way the hell overdue for a development-related post. I’ve long been a believer that one of the most important and most overlooked aspects of TDD is making sure the test fails first. To put it another way, here’s “Gandalf’s First Law of Unit Testing”: You shall not pass! â€” Gandalf the Grey, in his first (and last) TDD seminar

item.title: Methodologists
item.description: Once upon a time, way back before I was even married, much less a divorced dad, my brother Andy and I worked together at a certain company. This was my first professional job and the beginning of my long, sordid IT career and I owe it all to nepotism. Anyway, shortly after I started at this company, there was an internal change in management and our divisional president was replaced with a new hire - a fellow of South Asian extraction.

item.title: The most important effect of practicing TDD
item.description: For the last couple weeks, I’ve been helping to interview candidates for a vacancy on my company’s development team. Experience with TDD is not a prerequisite for our candidates (although openness to it certainly is), but occasionally we’ll get an applicant who claims to have some previous TDD experience at a previous position. One of the questions I always pose to a candidate in this category is “what would you say is the most important effect of practicing TDD?
